text.p: This is how major world bond markets were trading in late European business on Thursday.

GERMANY - German bonds were closed on Thursday for a market holiday. The June Bund future on the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (LIFFE) was trading at 101.73, down 0.03 from Wednesday's settlement price.

BRITAIN - Gilts took off late on Thursday climbing a full point from early session lows despite evidence from the CBI that buoyant high street conditions need reining in fast. The June long gilt future on LIFFE was trading at 113-28/32, up 19/32 from Wednesday's settlement price.
FRANCE - French bonds were closed on Thursday for a market holiday.

ITALY - Italian bonds and futures were slightly under par at the finish after Bunds and Treasuries undermined them at start. The June bond future on LIFFE was trading at 128.99 down 0.24 from Wednesday's settlement price.

UNITED STATES - U.S. Treasuries recouped some earlier losses at midmorning. Market trades were flat to lower amid lack of data. The June Treasury bond future on the Chicago Board of Trade was trading at 109-16/32, up 06/32 from Wednesday's settlement price. The long bond was quoted to yield 6.94 percent.

JAPAN - Key June Japanese government bond (JGB) futures ended Thursday's Tokyo session lower following poor six-year government bond auction results. In after hours trading the June future on LIFFE was trading at 123.86, down 0.79 from Wednesday's settlement price on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

EUROBONDS - The primary market ground to a halt on Thursday, with many European countries out of action due to Ascension day holidays. No new issues were launched on Thursday, and activity was likely to remain subdued until next week, dealers said.
Imperial Chemical Industries said it was watching international bond markets with a view to refinancing part of a $8.5 billion loan taken out to buy Unilever's specialty chemicals division.
